description: Carpenter v. United States - cell site location information tracking
facts: Police obtained 127 days of cell site location information
Data acquired from wireless carriers without warrant
Location data revealed Carpenter's movements over extended period
Government used third-party doctrine to justify warrantless access
CSLI showed Carpenter near robbery locations
asp_facts: case(carpenter). amendment(carpenter, fourth). surveillance_type(carpenter, cell_site_location). duration_days(carpenter, 127). warrant_obtained(carpenter, no). third_party_doctrine_claimed(carpenter, yes). detailed_location_tracking(carpenter, yes). movements_revealed(carpenter, yes). historical_records(carpenter, yes).
question: Does warrantless acquisition of historical cell site location information violate the Fourth Amendment?
rationale: The Government's acquisition of cell site records was a Fourth Amendment search. While the third-party doctrine applies in some contexts, accessing historical CSLI providing a detailed chronicle of a person's movements implicates privacy concerns requiring a warrant supported by probable cause.
legal_citations: Carpenter v. United States, 138 S. Ct. 2206 (2018)
